Epstein Flight Log 2004: A Year of Global Movement

The 2004 flight logs show Jeffrey Epstein at the height of his mobility. With no criminal investigations pending and his reputation intact among elite circles, Epstein traveled extensively. The manifests from this year document connections to powerful figures and reveal the logistical complexity of his operation.

2004 Flight Activity Overview

The 2004 logs show consistent, heavy use of Epstein's aviation assets:
  • Multiple aircraft - Including the Boeing 727 and smaller jets
  • International scope - Flights to Europe, Caribbean, and North America
  • High frequency - Often multiple flights per week
  • Complex routing - Multi-stop journeys common
This level of aviation activity represents significant financial resources and operational planning.

Major Destinations Documented

The 2004 flight logs record visits to:
  • Teterboro, New Jersey - Epstein's primary aviation hub
  • Palm Beach International - Regular Florida access
  • Cyril E. King Airport, St. Thomas - US Virgin Islands connection
  • Paris Le Bourget - French destination
  • London airports - Multiple UK visits
  • Santa Fe Municipal - New Mexico ranch access
These destinations reflect Epstein's property portfolio and international connections.

Notable 2004 Flight Patterns

Several patterns emerge from the 2004 logs:

The New York-Palm Beach Shuttle: Regular weekend flights between his Manhattan and Florida residences were common.

Island Access Routes: Flights to St. Thomas followed by helicopter or boat transfers to Little Saint James appear frequently.

European Circuits: Multi-week trips involving London, Paris, and other European cities.

Guest Transportation: Evidence of passengers being collected from various locations and brought to Epstein's properties.

Passenger Categories in 2004

Analysis of 2004 manifests reveals distinct passenger types:
  • Epstein himself - Present on majority of flights
  • Ghislaine Maxwell - Regular companion
  • Female passengers - Often identified only by first name
  • Professional associates - Business and financial figures
  • Academic connections - Scientists and researchers
  • Pilots and staff - Operational personnel
The diversity of passengers reflects Epstein's wide-ranging social and professional network.

2004 in Context

Understanding 2004 requires recognizing what wasn't happening: no police investigations, no media attention, no legal proceedings. Epstein operated freely, and his flight patterns show no indication of concern about scrutiny.

This makes the 2004 logs particularly valuable for understanding how his operation functioned without external pressure. The routes, timing, and passenger combinations reveal the system at its most natural state.
The 2004 flight logs document a sophisticated global travel operation connecting Epstein's various properties and associates. Without any legal pressure, the patterns revealed show how his network functioned at full capacity. These records became important evidence in later investigations, helping establish timelines, identify witnesses, and understand the logistical scope of his activities.
